data.heading: Scope
data.text:
The management of electronic transport regulations (METR) [SOURCE: ISO 24315-1:2024, 3.3.2.3] provides trustworthy, authoritative, machine-interpretable, transport-related rules for using the road network.

The scope of METR includes both rules that are relatively static (e.g., static speed limits) as well as those that are dynamic (e.g., variable speed limits, lane closures at incident scenes). However, where appropriate, METR is expected to incorporate existing standards (e.g., ISO/TS 19091 for signalized intersections).

The scope of METR includes the networks for pedestrians, public-area mobile robots (PMRs), micromobility vehicles, and motor vehicles.

This document defines requirements for the data that is to be exchanged among METR component systems. This document is presented in a format that is consistent with the guidance provided by ISO 29148 [2] for a system requirements document. 

The operational concept for METR is provided in ISO 24315-1.

attributesChanged.text:
The management of electronic transport regulations (METR) provides trustworthy, authoritative, machine-interpretable, transport-related rules for using surface transport facilities.

The scope of METR includes both rules that are relatively static (e.g., static speed limits) as well as those that are dynamic (e.g., variable speed limits, lane closures at incident scenes). However, where appropriate, METR is expected to incorporate existing standards (e.g., ISO/TS 19091 for signalized intersections).

This document defines the data requirements for METR systems in a format that is consistent with the guidance provided by ISO 29148 [2] for a system requirements document. 

For an understanding of how the METR distribution system fits into the larger METR system of systems, see ISO 24315-2. The operational concept for METR is provided in ISO 24315-1.

** Editor's Note: This draft document is generated from a requirements management tool. Headings within the draft document include a reference within square brackets (e.g., "[SoSR-35]") that indicate the source location of the text to assist in maintaining the text. These references will be removed in the final text. Text demarked with double asterisks ("**") are editorial notes that will be removed from the final draft. **

The management of electronic transport regulations (METR) provides trustworthy, authoritative, machine-interpretable, transport-related rules for using surface transport facilities.

The scope of METR includes both rules that are relatively static (e.g., static speed limits) as well as those that are dynamic (e.g., variable speed limits, lane closures at incident scenes). However, where appropriate, METR is expected to incorporate existing standards (e.g., ISO/TS 19091 for signalized intersections).

This document defines requirements for the data that is to be exchanged among METR component systems. This document is presented in a format that is consistent with the guidance provided by ISO 29148 [2] for a system requirements document. 

The operational concept for METR is provided in ISO 24315-1.

data.heading: Normative references
data.text: The following documents are referred to in the text in such a way that some, or all, of their content constitutes requirements of this document. For dated references, only the edition cited applies. For undated references, the latest edition of the referenced document (including any amendments) applies.

children.text: ISO/TS 14812, Intelligent transport systems — Vocabulary
ISO/TS 24315-1, Intelligent transport systems — Management of electronic traffic regulations (METR) — Part 1: Vocabulary
ISO/IEC/IEEE 24765, Systems and software engineering — Vocabulary

data.heading: Terms and definitions
data.text:
For the purposes of this document, the terms and definitions given in ISO/IEC/IEEE 24765, ISO/TS 14812 and ISO 24315-1 apply.

ISO and IEC maintain terminology databases for use in standardization at the following addresses:

•   ISO Online browsing platform: available at https://www.iso.org/obp

•   IEC Electropedia: available at https://www.electropedia.org

children.heading: Presentation of requirements
children.text:
The specific data requirements for METR are intended to be referenced by system-level requirements contained in ISO 24315 parts 3-6. They are presented in this document to minimize the duplication of text.

The requirements are presented as a logical data model. The actual structure and presentation of data within a conforming interface standard may vary from this logical model but all individual data requirements required by a system-level requirements standard shall be supported by conforming interface specifications.

attributesChanged.text: The specific data requirements for METR are intended to be referenced by system-level requirements contained in ISO 24315 parts 3-6. They are presented in this document to minimize the duplication of text.

The specific data requirements for METR are intended to be referenced by system-level requirements contained in ISO 24315 parts 3-6. They are presented in this document to minimize the duplication of text.

The requirements are presented as a logical data model. The actual structure and presentation of data within a conforming interface standard may vary from this logical model but all individual data requirements required by an implementation shall be supported by conforming implementations.

children.heading: Language Neutral
children.text: All data exchanged by METR shall be language-neutral.

children.heading: General
children.text: The METR catalogue allows METR distribution systems to publicize which categories of rules are fully available through the distribution system for the identified area.

children.heading: METR catalogue — Rule categorization scheme
children.text: The METR catalogue shall uniquely identify the scheme used to categorize rules within the catalogue.

attributesChanged.text:
The METR catalogue shall uniquely identify the scheme used to categorize rules within the catalogue. 

NOTE: While it is desirable to have all implementations use a single scheme, the identifier allows graceful evolution of the scheme over time as well as alternative schemes as deemed necessary.

The METR catalogue shall uniquely identify the scheme used to categorize rules within the catalogue. 

NOTE: While it is desirable to have all implementations use a single scheme, the identifier allows graceful migration to alternative schemes as deemed necessary - hopefully as a temporary solution until enhancements are incorporated into the next evolution of the standard scheme.

children.text: While it is desirable to have all implementations use a single scheme, the identifier allows graceful migration to alternative schemes as deemed necessary - hopefully as a temporary solution until enhancements are incorporated into the next evolution of the standard scheme.

children.heading: METR catalogue — Defined area
children.text: The METR catalogue shall identify each relevant defined area for which METR information can be provided.

attributesChanged.text: The METR catalogue shall identify each defined area for which METR information can be provided.

children.heading: METR catalogue — Supported pre-announced rule categories
children.text: For each defined area, the METR catalogue shall indicate the pre-announced rule categories supported for each vehicle category.

attributesChanged.text: The METR catalogue shall indicate the pre-announced rule categories supported for each vehicle category.

children.heading: METR catalogue — Supported ad-hoc rule categories
children.text: For each defined area, the METR catalogue shall indicate the ad-hoc rule categories supported for each vehicle category.

attributesChanged.text: The METR catalogue shall indicate the ad-hoc rule categories supported for each vehicle category.

children.heading: General
children.text: The METR information item class is an abstract generalized class that provides a common structure to data used by several other classes, including vehicle category, roadway category, user category, usage category, jurisdictional term, and transport rule.

attributesChanged.text: The METR information item class is an abstract generalized class that represents

children.text: The METR information item shall indicate the entity that translated the item into electronic format.

children.heading: General
children.text: The VehicleCategory class is a specialization of the jurisdictional term class that allows jurisdictions to precisely define what is meant by specific vehicle terms that might be used within rules (e.g., "truck").

children.heading: General
children.text: The UsageCategory class is a specialization of the jurisdictional term class that allows jurisdictions to precisely define what is meant by specific usage terms that might be used within rules (e.g., "HOV 2+", "hazardous goods").

children.heading: General
children.text: The JurisdictionalTerm class provides a formal declaration of the meaning of keywords used within transport rules.

attributesChanged.text:
Each jurisdictional term shall provide a formal declaration of the meaning of keywords used within transport rules.

EXAMPLE   The term "bus" can be defined as a "vehicle term" that includes "city buses operated by the local public transport authority".

children.heading: Jurisdictional term — Name
children.text: The JurisdictionalTerm shall identify the name of the term being defined.

children.heading: Jurisdictional term — Definition
children.text: The JurisdictionalTerm shall provide the legal definition of the term in the language in which it is legally defined.

attributesChanged.text: The JurisdictionalTerm shall provide the legal definition of the term in the language in which it is legally defined.

The JurisdictionalTerm shall provide the legal definition of the term in the language in which it is legally defined. 

NOTE: This is especially important when the standardized structures do not (yet) fully capture the natural language meaning.

The JurisdictionalTerm shall provide the legal definition of the term in the language in which it is legally defined. 

NOTE: The intent is that the standardized structure accurately captures the meaning of this text, but this allows a base level of support when the existing structures are not (yet) able to fully capture the natural language meaning.

children.text: The intent is that the standardized structure accurately captures the meaning of this text, but this allows a base level of support when the existing structures are not (yet) able to fully capture the natural language meaning.

children.heading: Jurisdictional term — Is fully represented
children.text: The JurisdictionalTerm shall indicate whether the legal term includes details that are only captured in the native language definition data element.

children.heading: Overview
children.text: A TransportRule is a specialization of METRInformation that defines regulatory, advisory, or guidance information. TransportRule information is segmented into two components. The primary rule information is the portion of the rule that is signed by the translator while the rule meta-data contains additional details about the rule that can change without requiring a new signature.

children.heading: Overview
children.text: The minimal rule information that interface standards shall include in the minimal attributes of a rule that are to be signed by the translation system and conveyed all the way to the user system without any modification.

attributesChanged.text: The primary rule information includes the minimal attributes of a rule that are to be signed by the translation system and conveyed all the way to the user system without any modification.

children.heading: Transport rule — Unique identifier
children.text: The identifier needs to be globally unique and is assumed to include the identify the source of the rule.

attributesChanged.text: NOTE: If a Map Update System translates a rule into a "map rule", it must also contain a reference to the unique identifier of the source rule so that a generic discrepancy handler can properly handle any discrepancy reports.

The identifier needs to be globally unique and is assumed to include the identify the source of the rule.

NOTE: If a Map Update System translates a rule into a "map rule", it must also contain a reference to the unique identifier of the source rule so that a generic discrepancy handler can properly handle any discrepancy reports.

children.text: speed restrictions

discussion.comment: Do vehicles need to know the speed limits of other vehicle types (e.g., do cars need to know the speed limit for trucks)? If there is a chance of a benefit and the cost is insignificant and perhaps simplifies the design, does it make sense to allow the sharing?

Should the category be "speed rules" and include advisory speeds or "speed regulations" and only identify regulatory speed limits (with advisories listed as a part of general)? What implication does this have on agencies translating rules prior to stating that they have all rules entered for an area?

children.heading: Transport rule — Type
children.text: Each rule shall identify the type of rule being defined, including the ability to report the following:
standard signage rules (e.g., those defined in ISO 14823-1)
an indication that temporary rules might exist without electronic equivalents

children.text: The TransportRule shall indicate the vehicle categories that it applies to, at least at a high level to be able to distinguish among the following categories:

children.heading: Transport rule — Trustworthiness assessment
children.text: The transport rule shall indicate a level of trustworthiness that is associated with the rule.

attributesChanged.text:
The transport rule shall indicate a level of trustworthiness that is associated with the rule.

NOTE: It is left to an interface specification to determine the details of this indication. It can be a provided several ways, such as by including several of the parameters identified in the list of supplemental attributes (e.g., translator type, confidence, etc.) or by combining these parameters into a single value.

children.heading: Flag suspect information
children.text: The METR information shall identify any areas where rule expiration times are approaching or past expiration (e.g., due to degraded system operations).

discussion.comment: Restructure the parent rule information flow and then move this requirement to the data requirements section.

attributesChanged.text: The rule information shall identify any areas where rule expiration times are approaching or past expiration (e.g., due to degraded system operations).

attributesChanged.text: the recommended interpretation of the discrepancy

children.heading: Overview
children.text: Each transport rule shall also be associated with the additional meta-data that must be accessible in some cases, but does not necessarily need to be included with what is normally distributed to vehicles.

children.heading: Transport rule — Translation agency type
children.text: the type of agency that translated the rule into an electronic record (e.g., government entity that issued rule, another governmental entity, private sector, crowd sourced)

children.heading: Transport rule — Verification type
children.text: information about the process used to verify the rule, including the entity that verified the rule, the method used to verify (e.g., verified by independent party, entered by store owner, crowd sourcing), and the time that it was last confirmed;

children.heading: Transport rule — Update time
children.text: the time that the rule was last approved;

attributesChanged.text: the time that the rule was last updated;

children.heading: Transport rule — Expiration time
children.text: The time the electronic rule loses trustworthiness.

children.heading: Transport rule — Entry status
children.text: Identifies the entry status of the rule (e.g., discovered, under review, approved, verified, etc.)

attributesChanged.heading: Transport rule — Status
attributesChanged.text: Identifies the approval status of the rule (e.g., discovered, under review, approved, verified, etc.)

children.heading: Supplemental data category
children.text: Needs to indicate characteristics about when/how likely supplemental data will be available when needed. For example, how likely is the emergency vehicle to broadcast that it is responding when only 70% of the emergency vehicle fleet is equipped?

For each supplemental data category, the catalogue shall identify the communication technology and parameters used to disseminate the data.

EXAMPLE  DSRC or wide area broadcast on a specific radio frequency

children.text: DSRC or wide area broadcast on a specific radio frequency

children.heading: Supplemental data type — Type
children.text: The SupplementalData shall indicate its type, which shall include:
signal timing information
environmental conditions
external conditions (e.g., workers present, pedestrian in crosswalk)
clock data
vehicle permit

attributesChanged.text: permit information

children.text: user permit
usage permit
emergency data (e.g., evacuation zones)

children.heading: Supplemental data type — Authority
children.text:
the amount of legal authority associated with the data. For example:

  1. Legally binding and intended as sole source
  2. High confidence but should be coupled with other available data
  3. Should be considered with all other information
  4. Believed to be accurate but cannot be relied upon as primary source
  5. Not trustworthy (i.e., testing mode)

children.heading: Supplemental data type — Expiration
children.text: The identification of the supplemental data provider shall indicate the maximum age of supplemental data received, prior to it being considered no longer trustworthy

attributesChanged.text: the maximum age of the supplemental data prior to it being considered no longer trustworthy
The identification of the supplemental data provider shall indicate the maximum age that the supplemental data can reach prior to it being considered no longer trustworthy

children.heading: Overview
children.text:
There are several classes that relate to discrepancies:

  1. A discrepancy fingerprint is used to uniquely identify a specific discrepancy report.
  2. A discrepancy report provides a complete report about a discrepancy as recorded from a field source. It is sent from a METR user to a discrepancy handling system and can be forwarded to a translator upon request.
  3. A consolidated discrepancy report is used by a discrepancy handling system to report a confirmed discrepancy in a summary fashion by omitting or summarizing details and redundancies contained in the individual discrepancy reports.
  4. A rule negotiation request can contain discrepancy reports as a part of its justification.

children.heading: Discrepancy fingerprint — METR information item id
children.text: The identifier of the METR information item(s) for which a discrepancy has been detected

children.heading: Discrepancy report — Type
children.text: A code that represents the type of error that is being reported. The code list shall include both a list of standard codes for standardized error types as well as code space reserved for enterprise-specific extensions to the list.

children.heading: Discrepancy report — Discrepancy logic model contact
children.text: The address that can be used to contact the developer of the system that generated the discrepancy report with an indication of the logic model used. The address should be specific enough to allow the developer to immediately understand the source  (e.g., the specific software product) that generated the discrepancy report.

attributesChanged.heading: Discrepancy report — Discrepancy logic contact
attributesChanged.text: The address that can be used to contact the developer of the system that generated the discrepancy report. The address should be specific enough to allow the developer to immediately understand the source  (e.g., the specific software product) that generated the discrepancy report.

The address that can be used to contact the developer of the system that generated the discrepancy report with an indication of the logic model used. The address should be specific enough to allow the developer to immediately understand the source  (e.g., the specific software product) that generated the discrepancy report.

The address that can be used to contact the developer of the system that generated the discrepancy report with an indication of the logic model used. The address should be specific enough to allow the developer to immediately understand the source  (e.g., the specific software product) that generated the discrepancy report.

NOTE: This should be treated as confidential information

children.text: This should be treated as confidential information

children.heading: Discrepancy report — Discrepancy logic release id
children.text: A identifier that uniquely indicates the release of the software that generated the discrepancy report. The identifier shall only increase in value over time so that receiving systems can determine when a new discrepancy report is being generated by a newer version of software.

attributesChanged.heading: Discrepancy report — Discrepancy generator release id
Discrepancy report — Discrepancy identifier release id

attributesChanged.text: A identifier that uniquely indicates the release of the software that generated the discrepancy report. The identifier shall only increase in value over time so that receiving systems can determine when a later version of the

children.heading: METR discrepancy report — Fingerprint
children.text: The discrepancy report shall include the METR discrepancy fingerprint.

attributesChanged.heading: METR discrepancy report — Discrepancy type
attributesChanged.text: e.g., missing TCD, location inconsistency, inconsistent electronic/physical rules, inconsistent electronic rules, etc.

children.heading: METR discrepancy report — Notes
children.text: The discrepancy report may include a notes field to provide a natural language description of the detected discrepancy. A note should be provided if the discrepancy type is not a standardized value.

attributesChanged.text:
The discrepancy report may include a notes field to provide a natural language description of the detected discrepancy. A note should be provided if the discrepancy type is not a standardized value.

NOTE:

children.heading: Rule discrepancy report — Location
children.text: The discrepancy report may include a location field that indicates the location where a discrepancy is relevant.

attributesChanged.text: Location associated with the detected discrepancy.

The discrepancy report may include a location field that indicates the location where a discrepancy is relevant.

NOTE: This is especially important in the case of discrepancies that are associated with a large area and the discrepancy report needs to refer to a more specific point. (e.g., reporting an inconsistency on a control zone sign when entering a control zone).

children.text: This is especially important in the case of discrepancies that are associated with a large area and the discrepancy report needs to refer to a more specific point. (e.g., reporting an inconsistency on a control zone sign when entering a control zone).

children.heading: Rule discrepancy report — Time
children.text: Indication of the date(s) and time(s) when the discrepancy was detected.

attributesChanged.text: Indication of the date and time when the discrepancy is believed to exist.
Indication of the date(s) and time(s) when the discrepancy is believed to exist.

Indication of the date(s) and time(s) when the discrepancy was detected.

NOTE: The timestamp can be especially valuable when the report has been delayed due to connectivity issues.

children.text: The timestamp can be especially valuable when the report has been delayed due to connectivity issues.

children.heading: METR discrepancy report — Supporting data
children.text: The discrepancy report should include any relevant supporting data that can be used to justify the generation of the report.

attributesChanged.text:
The discrepancy report should include any relevant supporting data that can be used to justify the generation of the report.

EXAMPLE  photo of the location showing a conflicting rule

children.text: photo of the location showing a conflicting rule

attributesChanged.text: The consolidated discrepancy report shall include a list, where each item includes:
The consolidated discrepancy report shall include a list of received reports, where each item in the list represents the same METR information item and each list item includes:

children.heading: General
children.text: The consolidated discrepancy report shall include a list of received reports, where each item in the list represents the same METR information item.
The consolidated discrepancy report shall include fingerprint associated with a set of discrepancy reports that indicate the type of vehicle reporting the discrepancy.

attributesChanged.text: discrepancy fingerprint
discrepancy logic model
discrepancy fingerprint
The consolidated discrepancy report shall include fingerprint for the discrepancy.

children.text: The consolidated discrepancy report shall include number of reports received with the indicated fingerprint;

attributesChanged.text: number of reports received
number of reports received with the indicated fingerprint
indication of the volume of reports being received with the indicated fingerprint
The consolidated discrepancy report shall include indication of the volume of reports being received with the indicated fingerprint

children.text: The consolidated discrepancy report shall include any notes associated with discrepancy fingerprint.

attributesChanged.text: notes associated with discrepancy fingerprint
any notes associated with discrepancy fingerprint;

children.text: The consolidated discrepancy report shall include any locations included in the discrepancy reports with the same fingerprint.

attributesChanged.text: any locations included in the discrepancy reports with the same fingerprint
any locations included in the discrepancy reports with the same fingerprint;

children.text: The consolidated discrepancy report shall include an indication of how many of the reports have additional data (e.g., supporting data).

attributesChanged.text: indication of how many of the reports have additional data (e.g., supporting data)

children.text: It is left to the interface design to determine if the volume of reports is based on a raw count, a count with timestamp information, a rate at which reports are being received, etc.

attributesChanged.text: NOTE: It is left to the interface design to determine if the volume of reports is based on a raw count, a count with timestamp information, a rate at which reports are being received, etc.

Each transport rule intended for repeated broadcast shall be associated with configuration parameters that specify details about how it will be broadcast.

EXAMPLE: The number of times the rule should be broadcasted over a period of time.
Each transport rule intended for repeated broadcast shall be associated with configuration parameters that specify details about how it will be broadcast.

children.heading: Rule broadcast — Configuration
children.text: Each transport rule intended for repeated broadcast shall be associated with configuration parameters that specify details about how it will be broadcast.
The number of times the rule should be broadcasted over a period of time.

children.heading: Rule broadcast — Operational status
children.text: Each component used to broadcast rules shall track properties about broadcast operations.

attributesChanged.heading: Status of rule broadcast
attributesChanged.text:
Each component used to broadcast rules shall track properties about the broadcast of each rule.

EXAMPLE   The number of times each rule has been broadcasted.

Each component used to broadcast rules shall track properties about broadcast operations.

EXAMPLE   The number of times each rule has been broadcasted.

children.heading: Distribution service — Access details
children.text: the mechanisms and parameters that can be used to connect to the METR distribution system

children.heading: Distribution service — Terms of service
children.text: Indication of any fees, rules on which map providers can be used, etc.

children.heading: Distribution service - Geographic areas
children.text: the geographic areas for which rules can be provided

children.heading: Distribution service - Rule categories
children.text: the rule categories (e.g., user classifications, vehicle classifications) that it can provide

children.heading: Information broadcast parameters
children.text: Defines how often an RSE should broadcast a rule

children.heading: Vehicle characteristics — Certifications
children.text: (e.g., ADS is qualified by jurisdiction for certain environments)

children.heading: Vehicle characteristics — License plate category
children.text: even/odd

children.heading: Vehicle characteristics — Mobility form
children.text: wheeled, tracked, ambulatory

children.heading: Vehicle characteristics — Unladen mass with battery
Vehicle characteristics — Unladen mass without battery
METR information for users
children.text: The METR information flow for users shall include:
Rule information
applicable vehicle categories
applicable user categories
applicable usage categories
applicable cargo categories

children.heading: General
children.text: This annex provides a tentative listing of the characteristics that might need to be recorded for each piece of METR information.

children.heading: Identifier
children.text: Every piece of METR information should be associated with a unique identifier for easy reference.

children.heading: Category
children.text: Each rule should be explicitly included in a METR information category so that the rule can be retrieved or filtered as appropriate for each user. For example, Annex D provides a list of potential categories that can be used to manage which rules are retrieved via METR.

children.heading: Source of information
children.text: Each piece of METR information should indicate the authority of the root source of the information. For example, is the source the actual rule-maker (i.e., individual with authority to enact the rule), a legally authorized representative of the rule-maker (e.g., hired staff of the rule-maker), a separate entity (e.g., a private private company that translates rules for areas where rule-makers do not provide METR information), or perhaps a separate entity whose information is approved in bulk by the rule-maker.

children.heading: Issuing authority
children.text: Each piece of METR information should identify the rule-maker that issued the information.

children.heading: Permit information
children.text: Some METR information might be associated with permits that grant an entity special privileges to use the public right of way (PROW) in ways that  potentially infringe upon others (e.g., the right to place scaffolding on sidewalks for building maintenance). When rules are associated with such permits, the permit information should be accessible.

children.heading: Enforcement information
children.text: A rule can include information on who is authorized to enforce the rule (e.g., the towing company where a towed vehicle can be found).

children.heading: Penalty information
children.text: A rule can include information about the penalties that can apply upon enforcement action (e.g., a maximum fine or fines doubled).

children.heading: Location
children.text: Rules are generally associated with locations, which are often referred to as a point location (i.e., a point when the path is viewed in a linear fashion), a linear location (i.e., a stretch along a curvilinear path), or an area location (i.e., an area that encompasses a portion of the surface - or near-surface, such as a bridge or tunnel - of the earth). Area locations can include specific defined areas or an entire jurisdiction. For example, rules might include stop signs or gates (i.e., point locations), on-street parking restrictions (i.e., linear locations), congestion zones (i.e., a custom area location), and rules related to the use of headlights (i.e., jurisdictional area locations).

attributesChanged.text: Rules are generally associated with locations, which might be defined by a road network point location, linear location, or area location. Area locations can include specific defined areas or an entire jurisdiction. For example, rules might include stop signs (i.e., point locations), on-street parking restrictions (i.e., linear locations), congestion zones (i.e., a custom area location), and rules related to the use of headlights (i.e., jurisdictional area locations).

Rules are generally associated with locations, which are often referred to as a point location (i.e., a point when the path is viewed in a linear fashion), linear location, or area location. Area locations can include specific defined areas or an entire jurisdiction. For example, rules might include stop signs (i.e., point locations), on-street parking restrictions (i.e., linear locations), congestion zones (i.e., a custom area location), and rules related to the use of headlights (i.e., jurisdictional area locations).

Rules are generally associated with locations, which are often referred to as a point location (i.e., a point when the path is viewed in a linear fashion), a linear location (i.e., a stretch along a curvilinear path), or an area location. Area locations can include specific defined areas or an entire jurisdiction. For example, rules might include stop signs (i.e., point locations), on-street parking restrictions (i.e., linear locations), congestion zones (i.e., a custom area location), and rules related to the use of headlights (i.e., jurisdictional area locations).

children.heading: Heading applicability
children.text: Some rules are only applicable to users that have a particular heading. For example, some northbound lanes might only have vehicle occupancy rules in the morning while southbound lanes only have vehicle occupancy rules in the evening.

children.heading: Map alignment
children.text: Some rules need higher location precision to be properly interpreted; mechanisms to provide the required precision need to be conveyed as a part of the rule. For example, while normal GNSS and mapping accuracy of a few meters is sufficient for warnings for animal crossings, parking space information needs typically needs to be accurate to within a few centimeters. Rules that require higher precision need to convey how the location information contained within the rule can accurately be represented into the real-world location (e.g., by identifying a local pavement marking or other landmark that can be used to provide a local reference point).

children.heading: Temporal characteristics
children.text: A rule can be associated with a schedule, hours of applicability, fuzzy times (e.g., "dawn", "holidays"), applicable days of week, applicable start and end dates, and other temporal constraints.

children.heading: Facility classification
children.text: Some rules only apply to certain classifications of roads/pathways. For example, an urban residential road is likely to have a different default speed limit than a rural motorway.

children.heading: Pavement type
children.text: Some rules apply to roads with certain pavement types. For example, gravel roads might be associated with a lower speed limit.

children.heading: Vehicle classification
children.text: Some rules apply to a specific set of vehicle classifications. For example, heavy vehicles might be restricted to certain lanes on a motorway.

children.heading: Vehicle physical dimensions
children.text: Some rules apply to the physical dimensions of a vehicle, such as its length, width, and/or height. For example, tall vehicles might be restricted from entering a tunnel.

children.heading: Vehicle mass
children.text:
Some rules apply to the mass (or weight) of a vehicle. For example:

  1. a bridge might prohibit vehicles above a specific weight
  2. a jurisdiction might require special registration of vehicles more than a specified mass

children.heading: Vehicle permits/tags
children.text:
Some rules apply to vehicles that are associated with an official permit. For example: 

  1. a vehicle might be issued a permit to park (or be parked) near the owner's residence 
  2. a vehicle might be equipped with a toll tag that allows it to use a tolled facility

NOTE: A vehicle permit is associated with the vehicle irrespective of the current occupants. Vehicle permits can be associated with expirations that occur due to time or due to change in registration.

children.heading: Vehicle certifications
children.text:
Some rules apply to vehicles with specific certification, which might be granted on a make and model basis. For example, a jurisdiction might require level 4 and 5 ADS-equipped vehicles to have distinct certificates to operate in specific environments, such as for:

  1. motorways, 
  2. roundabouts, 
  3. traffic circles,
  4. a specific (e.g., complex) interchange

children.heading: Fuel type
children.text: Some rules apply to vehicles based on the fuel type that they are using. For example, a central business district might restrict vehicles that are using diesel fuel.

children.heading: Emission profile
children.text: Some rules apply to vehicles based on their emissions profile. For example, an emission control zone might be restricted only to vehicles that meet ultra low emission vehicle standards.

children.heading: Vehicle equipment
children.text: Some rules apply to equipment that is associated with the vehicle. For example access to a road might be restricted to vehicles with snow chains.

children.heading: Trailers and attachments
children.text:
Some rules apply to vehicles with trailers. For example:

  1. a jurisdiction might restrict the number of trailers that can be attached to a vehicle
  2. a vehicle with a trailer might be restricted from using a specific roadway
  3. a vehicle with a carrier on the back might be required to have additional reflectors to designate the end of the carrier.

children.heading: Vehicle usage classification
children.text:
Some rules apply to a particular usage of a vehicle regardless of an official permit. For example: 

  1. some lanes on a motorway might be restricted to high occupancy vehicles
  2. a segment of kerbside might be restricted for passenger loading and unloading

children.heading: Cargo classifications
children.text: Some rules only apply to vehicles based on their cargo. For example, vehicles carrying dangerous goods might be restricted from entering a tunnel.

children.heading: Vehicle usage permits
children.text: Some rules apply to a vehicles associated with an official permit related to vehicle usage. For example, a stretch of kerbside might be restricted to vehicles with permits related to ridesourcing operations.

children.heading: User classification
children.text:
Some rules apply to particular classifications of users. For example:

  1. Commercial vehicle operators might be required to stop at check points
  2. Police officers and emergency responders might be allowed to use turn around lanes on a motorway

children.heading: User permits
children.text:
Some rules apply to a users associated with an official permit. For example:

  1. a user might be issued a permit to park a vehicle near the user's residence 
  2. a user might be issued a permit to park in accessible parking spaces

NOTE: A user permit is associated with the user and can be moved between vehicles as needed.

children.heading: General
children.text: The meaning and/or activity status of some rules (e.g., signal timing, pull over for emergency vehicle, lower speed when raining) is dependent upon supporting data. The rules need to identify such cases along with the acceptable source(s) for the supporting data.

children.heading: Environmental conditions
children.text:
Some rules only apply when certain environmental conditions are present. For example:

  1. lower speed limits might apply during rain
  2. parking restrictions might take affect due to snow 
  3. certain vehicles might be restricted when air pollution exceeds certain levels

children.heading: External conditions
children.text: Some rules only apply when certain external conditions exist that might be difficult for vehicle-based sensors to detect. For example, speed limits might be reduced when workers or children are present.

children.heading: Emergency conditions
children.text: Some rules only apply when certain emergency conditions exist that might be difficult for vehicle-based sensors to detect. For example, access to specific streets might be restricted due to a terrorist threat level

children.heading: On-board data
children.text: Some rules might apply only when on-board sensors detect specific conditions (e.g., rain detected, driver fatigue detected).
